Grivot's Richebourg is superb.  With a perfumed nose of black fruits, flowers, and toasty new oak, and an intense, concentrated style, this medium-bodied, tannic, powerful wine requires 7-8 years of cellaring.
Grivot's 1993s raise few questions as to whether the fruit will be present when the wines reach their apogees.  Among the most profoundly colored wines of the vintage, they all possess opaque, saturated purple/black robes.  None of Grivot's 1993s were fined, but they were bottled with a light polishing filtration.
Much has been made of the fact that Grivot was a follower of Guy Accad.  Because of that he has, in my opinion, been unfairly criticized.  While Accad had influence over the winemaking, offering advice both in the vineyard and the winery, Grivot had full control over all aspects of his vineyards and cellars.  Accad's presence in Grivot's cellars is no longer in evidence, as Grivot is one more client to abandon Accad's revolution. I thought Grivot's 1993s were some of the finest wines this estate has made in decades.  Grivot's wines tend to be robust, rich, and generally ageworthy.  That being said, except for the most concentrated vintages I would opt for drinking his wines within 10-12 years of the vintage.  Certainly there is no lack of fruit extract in this domaine's 1993s.
 Importer: Chateau and Estate Wine Co., New York, NY; tel. (212) 572-7725

Much has been made of the fact that Grivot was a follower of Guy Accad.  Because of that he has, in my opinion, been unfairly criticized.  While Accad had influence over the winemaking, offering advice both in the vineyard and the winery, Grivot had full control over all aspects of his vineyards and cellars.  Accad's presence in Grivot's cellars is no longer in evidence, as Grivot is one more client to abandon Accad's revolution. I thought Grivot's 1993s were some of the finest wines this estate has made in decades.  Grivot's wines tend to be robust, rich, and generally ageworthy.  That being said, except for the most concentrated vintages I would opt for drinking his wines within 10-12 years of the vintage.  Certainly there is no lack of fruit extract in this domaine's 1993s.
 Importer: Chateau and Estate Wine Co., New York, NY; tel. (212) 572-7725

The Echezeaux was superb in 1987, but I could not help noticing it smelled like Syrah rather than Pinot Noir. Skeptics of the Guy Accad style of winemaking will say the wine does not taste like Echezeaux. However, it is a great wine, impressively colored, rich, and full. This is a wine to drink by 1996-1997 and appreciate for its wonderfully pure, hedonistic, seductive fruit and voluptuous texture.
The Nuits St.-Georges Les Boudots has an almost black/ruby color, long deep, jammy, black fruit flavors, medium to full body, and a smooth finish. This Premier Cru should drink well until 1995-1996.

The Vosne-Romanee Les Beaux Monts, with its deep, dark ruby color, big, rich, jammy bouquet, medium to full body, and lush, silky finish is certainly of high quality. This Premier Cru should drink well until 1995-1996.
The Nuits St.-Georges Les Boudots has black fruits in the nose and tastes of plums, has plenty of toasty, vanilla-scented new oak, and a less alcoholic feel than the Clos Vougeot.
The Clos Vougeot is lovely, with a velvety, berry fruitiness, plenty of spicy oak, medium body, excellent fragrance, and balance. Drink it between 1992-1993.
The Richebourg is backward, concentrated, and long, but in need of cellaring until 1992-1993. It may ultimately merit a much higher score.
The Nuits St.-Georges Premier Cru is light, though it is still fruity and soft. It should be drunk between 1991-1992.

The Clos Vougeot should be cellared until 1990-1992, when it will fully open. It has exceptionally pure Pinot fruit, medium to full body, fine depth, and plenty of tannin. The young Etienne Grivot, who now runs this estate in addition to making the wines of the Domaine Jacqueline Jayer, is one of Burgundy's most promising talents. The emphasis here is on pure, elegant, finely etched Pinot Noir fruit. The wine is never too alcoholic or tannic, but rather a prototype for the delicate style of Pinot.

The Nuits St.-Georges Les Boudots exhibits silky, strawberry, cherry fruitiness, a touch of toasty new oak, and plenty of depth underneath some good tannins. The young Etienne Grivot, who now runs this estate in addition to making the wines of the Domaine Jacqueline Jayer, is one of Burgundy's most promising talents. The emphasis here is on pure, elegant, finely etched Pinot Noir fruit. The wine is never too alcoholic or tannic, but rather a prototype for the delicate style of Pinot.

The Villages Vosne-Romanee, while light in color, offers moderately intense strawberry-scented fruit and a soft texture. The young Etienne Grivot, who now runs this estate in addition to making the wines of the Domaine Jacqueline Jayer, is one of Burgundy's most promising talents. The emphasis here is on pure, elegant, finely etched Pinot Noir fruit. The wine is never too alcoholic or tannic, but rather a prototype for the delicate style of Pinot.

The 2000 Echezeaux explodes from the glass with plummy black cherries. Medium-bodied, plush, and supple, it slathers the palate with creamed cherries. This satin-textured beauty is feminine, seamless, and has delightful clarity of flavors as well as a lengthy, edge-free finish. Anticipated maturity: now-2010. 

Concerning the 2000s, Grivot said it was “a superb vintage, one of my finest. The grapes had great ripeness, with sufficient freshness.

Importer: Diageo Chateau and Estate Wines Company, New York, NY; tel. (212) 572-7725

Mocha, cherries, and cedar can be detected in the nose of the 2000 Clos Vougeot. Deep and intensely flavored, it boasts a blackberry, cassis, currant, cedar, and earth-laced character. Its admirably long, expressive finish reveals loads of ripe tannin. Anticipated maturity: 2004-2010. 

Concerning the 2000s, Grivot said it was “a superb vintage, one of my finest. The grapes had great ripeness, with sufficient freshness.

Importer: Diageo Chateau and Estate Wines Company, New York, NY; tel. (212) 572-7725

The 2000 Nuits-St.-Georges Les Charmois exhibits scents reminiscent of cedar-laced spices. Easygoing, soft, and ripe, it presents lovely spiced black cherry fruit in its light to medium-bodied character. Drink it over the next 4 years.    

Concerning the 2000s, Grivot said it was “a superb vintage, one of my finest. The grapes had great ripeness, with sufficient freshness.

Importer: Diageo Chateau and Estate Wines Company, New York, NY; tel. (212) 572-7725

Delightful red cherry aromas are found in the nose of the 2000 Vosne-Romanee. Medium-bodied, it displays a lush, spicy personality filled with supple black cherries. Its finish is firm. Projected maturity: now-2008. 

Concerning the 2000s, Grivot said it was “a superb vintage, one of my finest. The grapes had great ripeness, with sufficient freshness.

Importer: Diageo Chateau and Estate Wines Company, New York, NY; tel. (212) 572-7725

The medium to dark ruby-colored 1999 Echezeaux offers a nose of intense blackberry and fresh herb aromas. Medium to full-bodied, rich, and ample, it is crammed with lush layers of cherries, blackberries, and spices. This sexy, extroverted wine has loads of sweet tannin in its personality. It is seamless, fruit-packed, and exciting. Drink it over the next 12 years. 

Importer: Seagram Chateau and Estate Wines Company, New York, NY; tel. (212) 572-7725.

The ruby-colored 1999 Vosne-Romanee Les Beaux Monts has dramatic red fruit aromas. An intense wine, it has a plush, juicy, highly detailed, sweet, black cherry-filled flavor profile. Its character is tangy, lively, and reveals an extremely long, focused, and soft finish. 

Importer: Seagram Chateau and Estate Wines Company, New York, NY; tel. (212) 572-7725.

Sweet raspberries, red currants, and fresh herbs can be found in the aromatics of the 1999 Vosne-Romanee Les Suchots. Medium-bodied and silky-textured, it is firm and masculine. Cherries, strawberries, and raspberries dominate its expressive, structured character. Projected maturity: 2003-2008. 

Importer: Seagram Chateau and Estate Wines Company, New York, NY; tel. (212) 572-7725.

The floral and perfumed aromas of the ruby-colored 1999 Nuits-St.-Georges Les Boudots lead to an ample, satin-textured, and medium-bodied personality. This lush, broad, and rich wine has excellent to outstanding depth of candied cherries in its delightfully velvety personality. Drink it over the next 8 years. 

Importer: Seagram Chateau and Estate Wines Company, New York, NY; tel. (212) 572-7725.

The ruby-colored 1999 Clos Vougeot has gorgeously spicy, pure, raspberry aromas. Medium-bodied and refined, it is a harmonious, gorgeously ripened, satin-textured offering. Asian spices are intermingled with currants, raspberries, and cherries in this sweet, tannin-packed wine. It is a feminine, precise, and pure Clos Vougeot to be drunk over the next 9 years. 

Importer: Seagram Chateau and Estate Wines Company, New York, NY; tel. (212) 572-7725.

The ruby-colored 1999 Nuits-St.-Georges Les Roncieres has a perfumed, talcum powder, and sweet berry-scented nose. Medium-bodied and rich, it has excellent grip as well as balance. Loads of sweet, dark cherries can be found in this seamless, elegant, yet highly expressive wine. It reveals beautifully ripened tannin in its long, supple finish. This is an offering that will be delicious upon release, and should age well for up to 8 or 9 years. 

Importer: Seagram Chateau and Estate Wines Company, New York, NY; tel. (212) 572-7725.

The spectacular 1997 Richebourg offers an enthralling, talcum powder, perfume, and red cherry-scented nose.  This bold, expressive, powerful wine possesses the breed and intensity associated with its heralded vineyard.  Immensely complex and muscular, this complete offering is masculine, refined, ample, and crammed with super-ripe cherries immersed in spices and black pepper.  Drink this beauty over the next dozen years.

Importer: Seagram Chateau and Estate Wines Company, New York, NY; tel; (212) 572-7725.

The 1997 Clos Vougeot is medium to dark ruby-colored, and reveals an extremely ripe nose of dark berries, spices, and perfume.  This magnificent offering bursts on the palate with black fruits, Asian spices, cherries, and hints of licorice.  Medium to full-bodied, powerful, expansive, broad, and yet elegant, this is a first-rate wine from a generally underachieving grand cru vineyard.  Its forward, sur-maturite-laced fruit lead to a somewhat austere and structured, yet supple tannin-packed, long finish.  Projected maturity: 2001-2008.  Importer: Seagram Chateau and Estate Wines Company, New York, NY; tel; (212) 572-7725.

Harvested at 13.8% natural potential alcohol, the ruby-colored 1997 Nuits-St.-Georges Les Pruliers displays over-ripe grapey aromas interspersed with earth and spices.  It is massive, expressive, powerful, and bold.  Meaty black fruits, stones, and briary-flavors saturate the palate and linger for 30+ seconds.  My score will appear overly conservative if this boisterous offering gains complexity and focus with cellaring.  Projected maturity: now-2006+.  Importer: Seagram Chateau and Estate Wines Company, New York, NY; tel; (212) 572-7725.

The backward, foursquare, and structured 1997 Nuits-St.-Georges Les Boudots has a medium-to-dark ruby color.  Medium-to-full-bodied, it displays earth, flowers, and black fruits in its aromatics.  On the palate, precise metal, brambleberry, game, stone, and blackberry flavors can be discerned in this firm offering.  Anticipated maturity: 2002-2007+.

Importer: Seagram Chateau and Estate Wines Company, New York, NY; tel; (212) 572-7725.

Crafted from a parcel in the south-western corner of the Echezeaux vineyard, in a lieu-dit called Les Cruots, Grivot's 1997 is medium-to-dark ruby-colored and reveals black raspberry as well as cherry aromas.  It offers admirable ripeness and breadth, a medium-to-full body, as well as loads of flowers, spices, black/red berries, and toasted oak flavors.  This refined wine will require moderate patience due to its somewhat firm structure.  Anticipated maturity: 2003-2008.

Importer: Seagram Chateau and Estate Wines Company, New York, NY; tel; (212) 572-7725.

The medium-to-dark ruby-colored 1997 Vosne-Romanee Les Suchots reveals rose, violet, and cherry aromas.  This is an oily-textured, thick, and dense wine with excellent grip.  Loads of tangy currants and assorted red berries are found in its medium-bodied, smile-inducing personality.  Drink it over the next 6 years.  Importer: Seagram Chateau and Estate Wines Company, New York, NY; tel; (212) 572-7725.

It offers a gorgeously bright medium-to-dark ruby color and extraordinary fragrances of super-ripe plums, cherries, and morel mushrooms. This brooding, powerful, full-bodied, mouth-coating, and refined block-buster is crammed with awesomely sweet black raspberries, cherries, candied strawberries, cassis, stones, and raw meat flavors that last throughout its unending finish. Wow! Bravo!

Even though I have a stated policy of only reviewing wines that have completed their malo-lactic fermentations, I decided to make an exception for this spectacular wine. First, its malos were virtually finished, and secondly, readers deserve to know about this wine's sublime qualities.

"The most important thing for me is harmony. I don't want hard and tannic wines. Those that are too tannic will never be good." So stated Etienne Grivot, the tall, intelligent, Basset Hound-eyed, and youngish man in charge of the domaine that bears his father's name. This estate produces some of Burgundy's finest wines, and consumers need to search them out before their prices reflect their quality.

Importer: Chateaux and Estates Wine Co., New York, NY; Tel; (212) 572-7725.

This wine is a stunning example of this all-too-often weak grand cru. It possesses enthralling aromas of black raspberries, dark cherries, beef blood, and Asian spices that give way to an oily-textured, magnificently concentrated, highly-refined, and very focused personality. This superbly sweet and lush offering is feminine, opulent, well-structured, and powerful. Its prodigiously long finish reveals loads of soft tannins. Drink it between 2003 and 2010.

Note: This wine had finished its malo-lactic fermentation in September, 1997, and had been racked and sulphured two weeks before my visit. This process can have the effect of temporarily drying out the fruit and decreasing the intensity of color in wines. If anything, it  will become darker, have more body, and be lusher than my notes would suggest.

Importer: Chateaux and Estates Wine Co., New York, NY; Tel; (212) 572-7725.

This dark-colored has a rich, fragrant, blackberry and toasted oak-scented nose as well as a marvelously concentrated, full-bodied, super-ripe, elegant, deeply rich, and velvety character. This wine has layers of intense and sweet black cherries, Asian spices, hints of minerals and grilled oak flavors which coat the palate throughout its long and persistent finish. Anticipated maturity: 2003-2009.

Note: This wine had finished its malo-lactic fermentation in September, 1997, and had been racked and sulphured two weeks before my visit. Exhibiting a medium-to-dark ruby color and fabulous aromas of black cherries, flowers, Asian spices, and toasty oak, this wine has extraordinary richness, depth, and refinement. This medium-to-full-bodied, silky, complex, focused, and fat wine is filled with tangy red currants, cherries, candied orange peels, and a firm structure. This admirably long wine should be at its peak between 2002 and 2008.

Note: This wine had finished its malo-lactic fermentation in September, 1997, and had been racked and sulphured two weeks before my visit. This deep ruby/purple-colored wine offers aromas of strongly spiced black cherries dusted with earth. This rich, concentrated, dense, full-bodied, and thick wine is crammed with blackberries, cherries, cassis, stones, Asian spices, and toasted oak. Projected maturity: 2003-2009.

Note: This wine had finished its malo-lactic fermentation in September, 1997, and had been racked and sulphured two weeks before my visit. This process can have the effect of temporarily drying out the fruit and decreasing the intensity of color in wines. Readers should note that the 2013 Meursault 1er Cru Charmes will not be commercialized because the production will constitute a special cuvée for Patrick’s grandchild. It has a lovely honeyed nose and great weight in the mouth, quite dense and almost viscous with plenty of tropical notes furnishing the finish. All I can say is what a lucky grandchild! I'll refrain for scoring this and maybe they'll open a bottle for me in 18-years time.

Tasted blind at the Burgundy 2011 horizontal tasting in Beaune. The nose on Javillier’s 2011 Corton-Charlemagne Grand Cru is a little reticent at first, but dunk your nose deep into the glass and there are attractive lime leaf and orange rind aromas that emerge. There is a bit of SO2 dampening the aromatics so I grace this with an hour’s decanting. The palate is clean and fresh with touches of mango and lemon curd, then nectarine and persimmon coming through on the well-defined but tightly coiled finish. This has good substance but it needs 5 or 6 years in the cellar.

The 2012 Meursault Les Tillets is Patrick Javillier’s largest holding at 1.5-hectares on limestone-rich, very thin soils, the vines ostensibly penetrating directly into the rock. Here he employs around 30% new oak. It has a very focused bouquet with scents of lime cordial and chalk, the oak neatly folded into the fruit and barely noticeable. The palate is finely balanced with a touch more tension and citric compared to the Clos du Cromin, the finish fresh and lively with again, just a dash of lemongrass pricking the tip of the tongue after the wine has departed. This represents another excellent 2012. 

Patrick Javillier was busy down in his Meursault winery when I called in at the property that was established by Raymond Javillier after the war, when he set about acquiring parcels of vine around the village. Yet the main focus of the business was in purchasing fruit from courtiers. Patrick himself vinified his first wine in 1974 after completing his winemaking diploma at the University of Burgundy and steadily built up a raft of long-term contracts, tending holdings through fermage agreements. Since 2008, his daughter Marion has looked after and vinified the red wines and it was clear that Patrick takes a great deal of pride in them. I have been following Javillier’s wines for a number of years now. Here is a man determined to transcend the limitations of possessing propitious terroirs, but few premier and grand cru vines. How does he overcome them? Well, simply by straightforward winemaking tenets: complete de-stemming for the reds, remaining faithful to his trusty old Vaslin press (which was recuperating in the corner after the vintage), skillful use of new oak and by assiduously blending small parcels whose final wine is often more than a sum of its parts. Patrick told me that he commenced picking on September 12 with potential alcohol levels coming in between 12.0 and 12.9 degrees. These wines often represent outstanding value and we commence with his two generic whites that offer outstanding value year after year.

Importer: A Peter Vezan Selection (various importers), Paris; fax 01 33 1 42 55 42 93

Javillier rued the fact that he has so little premier cru when he dipped into thieve the solitary one-year-old piece of his 2012 Meursault 1er Cru Les Charmes, which comes from his diminutive 0.06-hectare parcel. It lives up to its name with an understated but charming bouquet that is very well-defined with traces of peach and rosewater. The palate is very well-balanced with a rounded, smooth, mint-tinged entry, very nicely judged acidity and a gorgeous, svelte, citrus finish with touches of apricot and mango. Divine. Patrick Javillier purchased his small (0.17-hectare) parcel of vines in Corton-Charlemagne in 1999 within the lieu-dit of “Les Pougets.” He joked that he produces around 1,050 bottles: those 50 bottles being very important.

The 2012 Meursault Cuvee Tete de Murger has a precise, more floral bouquet with scents of buttercup and nettles infusing the bright, citric fruit. There is also a suggestion of dried honey and almond. The palate is well-balanced with a little more roundness than the other Meursault cuvees and it feels a little fatter and voluminous in the mouth. It builds nicely in the mouth with touches of spice furnishing the long finish. This should turn out to be a feisty Meursault that will bring plenty of joy over six to eight years.

The 2012 Meursault Les Clousots is a blend of two lieux-dits: “Les Crotots” and “Les Clous” since Patrick Javillier believes that their marriage represents more than a sum of its parts. After the fireworks of the Clos du Cromin and the Les Tillets, the Les Clousots takes everything down a notch: much more introspective and broody on the nose with tertiary notes emerging with aeration, then broom and white fennel. The palate is nicely balanced and pure on the entry, the 20-25% new oak again neatly absorbed into the fruit profile. There is a palpable sense of energy and frisson toward the finish, although I would have liked just a little more persistency in the mouth. Perhaps this will develop with bottle age because I think that this has great potential. Patrick Javillier has produced his Cuvee Tete de Murger since 1997, a blend of two parcels (“Les Casse-Tetes” and “Les Murgers de Monthelie”) that like Les Clousots, he sees as more than a sum of its parts.

The 2012 Bourgogne Blanc Cuvee Oligocene comes from vines in Meursault next to Puligny in the lieu-dit of Les Pellands, although Patrick’s vines are situated not within the premier cru section of the vineyard, ergo they are labeled as generic white Burgundy, the cuvee named after the geological period of the rock formation. Its limestone soils encourages Patrick to use a little more new oak, around 30%, as hebelieves it is fully absorbed within one year. It has a more vibrant, intense bouquet than the Cuvee de Forgets and as usual it carries that new oak with ease. The palate is fresh and vibrant, the minerality showing through very well and infusing the vivacious finish with lime cordial and hints of orange zest. About the best generic Burgundy money can buy. Patrick uses minimal, preferably zero new oak for his Clos du Cromin cuvee because of its rich, clay soils.

The 2012 Savigny-les-Beaune 1er Cru Les Serpentieres is Javillier’s sole red premier cru. It has a pleasant bouquet of raspberry preserve and orange blossom that opens nicely in the glass, though it does not aspire to great complexity. The palate is fresh and clean with good acidity. The tannins feel firm and slightly chalky in the mouth, the finish tightly wound and demonstrating fine minerality if not the persistency one might have discerned in say, 2009 or 2010. Still, this should become a very respectable, and yet a delicious Savigny-les-Beaune.

The 2012 Bourgogne Blanc Cuvee de Forgets comes from 2.25 hectares of vines within the commune Meursault in Les Herbeux and Les Vaux, that lies adjacent to Volnay. It comes from clayey soils and is matured in 20-25% new oak. It has a generous bouquet with clean and pure tropical scents – touches of peach and apricot. The palate is clean and a little spicy on the entry, leaving a slight tingle at the sides of the mouth, with a long, harmoniously supple finish. Not a white Burgundy to forget. 

Patrick Javillier was busy down in his Meursault winery when I called in at the property that was established by Raymond Javillier after the war, when he set about acquiring parcels of vine around the village. Yet the main focus of the business was in purchasing fruit from courtiers. Patrick himself vinified his first wine in 1974 after completing his winemaking diploma at the University of Burgundy and steadily built up a raft of long-term contracts, tending holdings through fermage agreements. Since 2008, his daughter Marion has looked after and vinified the red wines and it was clear that Patrick takes a great deal of pride in them. I have been following Javillier’s wines for a number of years now. Here is a man determined to transcend the limitations of possessing propitious terroirs, but few premier and grand cru vines. How does he overcome them? Well, simply by straightforward winemaking tenets: complete de-stemming for the reds, remaining faithful to his trusty old Vaslin press (which was recuperating in the corner after the vintage), skillful use of new oak and by assiduously blending small parcels whose final wine is often more than a sum of its parts. Patrick told me that he commenced picking on September 12 with potential alcohol levels coming in between 12.0 and 12.9 degrees. These wines often represent outstanding value and we commence with his two generic whites that offer outstanding value year after year.

Importer: A Peter Vezan Selection (various importers), Paris; fax 01 33 1 42 55 42 93

The 2012 Savigny-les-Beaune Les Grands Liards was tasted from vat and comes from their 45- and 10-year-old vines (0.54-hectares). It has an uncomplicated briary-scented nose that unfolds nicely with encouragement in the glass. The palate is crisp and light with straightforward, chewy red fruit and a light grip on the white pepper-tinged finish.

There are just two pieces of the 2012 Pernand-Vergelesses Village this year. The nose is neat and tidy: quite conservative with light blackberry and raspberry fruit, aromatics wishing to spring no surprises. The palate is bright and chunky with slightly coarse tannins at the moment. It builds nicely with a little more weight than the Savigny, but is still just a little short in the mouth. The usual five pieces of Aloxe-Corton was reduced to two this year.

The 2012 Aloxe-Corton Village has a pleasant bouquet of raspberry preserve and fresh strawberry – dainty and pure. The palate is simple with a sappy opening of black cherry and a touch of fresh prune, while the acidity well-judged though the finish is a little “blocky” at the moment. This will serve as decent early drinking Aloxe-Corton.

The 2011 Bourgogne Blanc Cuvee des Forgets has a simple, straightforward bouquet with apple-blossom and freshly sliced pear. The palate is crisp on the entry, harmonious with an herbaceous edge. This is more about texture than delivering a payload of fruit, but one can appreciate the neutral finish that would show better accompanied by cuisine. Drink now-2015. 

Importer: Martin Scott Wines; www.martinscottwines.com

The 2009 Meursault Les Clousots offers lively fresh, zesty fruit on the nose, with fine vigor and tension, actually putting the Les Tillets 2009 in its place. The palate is fresh and lively, revealing concentrated, crisp citrus fruit infused with ginger and a touch of rhubarb on the composed, focused finish. This is a superb showing. Drink now-2018.

The 2009 Meursault Tete Murger Javiller (from “Les Castet” and “Murger de Monthelie”) has a strict, linear bouquet with lovely poise, subtle scents of wild honey emerging with time. The palate has great attack at the front of the mouth. It is underpinned by crisp green fruit – subtle notes of gooseberry and cooking apple followed by a nicely defined, unpretentious finish. Very fine. Drink now-2019.

The 2009 Meursault Les Tillets offers a light, earthy bouquet with moderate definition. Hints of freshly cut pear and nectarine develop with aeration and are subsequently joined by jasmine. The palate is finely balanced with well-judged acidity. It opens nicely toward the peachy finish, which has plenty of weight, if not the finesse of a top Les Tillets. Drink now-2018.
There appears to be a lot of reduction on the nose of the 2009 Meursault 1er Cru Clos Cromin. Simply, rather smudged, it trails behind Javillier’s fellow 2009s. I will seek to re-taste this.

Lemon, violet, and chalk dust on the nose of Javillier’s 2007 Corton-Charlemagne lead to a palate with refreshing fruit touched by chalk, honey, nut oils, and the complimentary astringency of lemon pip and peach kernel. This combines formidable sheer density with vivacity and lift, finishing with invigorating length. While nature did not increase the amount of Charmes produced this year, there are all of three and a half barriques (all used once previous) – the largest volume ever – of this beauty. I would anticipate it improving over a number of years and performing brilliantly for a decade.

Patrick Javillier began picking on September 3rd, but only finished (with his Savigny) mid-month. He chaptalized lightly, keeping all of the wines under 13%. He thinks his 2007 results capture “the spirit and purity of 1984, but with less acidity, and perhaps a bit that of 1979.” But the wines of Javillier were very different and far less exciting even a dozen years ago than they are today, so in that sense these comparisons are moot. (His favorites for drinking now, by the way, are his 1990s.) And I have never tasted a more impeccably balanced or consistently delicious and intriguing collection at this address than these 2007s. For some general notes on Javillier’s approach to vinification, consult my report in issue 180.

A Peter Vezan Selection (various importers), Paris; fax 011 33 1 42 55 42 93

The latest installment of the marriage he arranged between Casse Tete and Les Murgers, Javillier’s 2007 Meursault Tete de Murgers evinces scents of toasted grain and grapefruit zest, but also brine, sweat, white pepper, passion fruit, mint, and chicken stock – an amalgam that put me a bit in mind of Chablis, or – in all honesty (and with no offense meant!) – Saint-Bris or Pouilly-Fume. Nobody can claim the nose here lacks diversity, and this sets up an energetic oscillation between fruit (luscious grapefruit and honeydew melon) and mineral notes on the palate that will keep you fascinated and delighted. Not just the reprise of citrus zest, mint, white pepper, and salt in the finish but also the virtually vibratory sense of energy displayed makes this uncommonly invigorating. It might not be classic Meursault, but it is a gorgeous wine. How well it will age I can only guess (6 or more years?), but certainly do not miss drinking some young!

Lemon, fresh apricot, chalk dust, and somehow cooling high-toned green herbal notes in the nose of Javillier’s 2007 Meursault Les Tillets lead to a shimmering palate exchange of bright citrus, put fruits, chalk and salt. This wine displayed exceptional buoyancy and poise even in the 2006 vintage, and in a vintage where those characteristics are far more common, it’s little wonder that this 2007 reveals such lift, liveliness, invigoration and elegance. It also evinces a flattering creaminess. I would anticipate at least 6-8 years of reward here.

There are again only one and a half barriques of Javillier’s 2007 Meursault Charmes, which smells of ripe peach, cherry distillate and honeysuckle; comes to the palate with an impressive sense of density, and a balance of creaminess and vivacity, its fruit accented by peach kernel, toasted almond, lemon zest, and chalk dust; and finishes with real grip, and chalky, alkaline minerality to accompany its succulent fruit. Here is a paradigm of vintage virtues as well as an especially engaging expression of its great site. I suspect it will be worth following for at least 6-8 years.

The 2007 Meursault Les Clous-ots represents Javillier’s second vintage combining fruit from Les Clous and a recently-acquired parcel in Les Crotots (a site below Poruzots). Ripe peach, fresh lemon, and freshly-milled grains in the nose lead to a luscious, juicy palate in which honeydew melon seems to accompany the aforementioned features. This is almost delicate in its sense of lift, caressing texture, and subtle but insistent citric refreshment. While lacking quite the interplay or poise of the Tillets, it is very impressive indeed – all the way through to a chalk-tinged, persistently generously-fruited finish. I suspect it will be best enjoyed within 4-5 years.

Javillier’s single-vineyard 2007 Bourgogne Cuvee Oligocene – a wine that habitually transcends its appellation – combines high-toned kirsch, almond and pistachio oil, luscious pink grapefruit; and a predictable chalkiness, crystalline minerality, and saline savor on a palate of unusual creaminess for young Oligocene. A great many premier cru Meursault – even from the excellent estates whose wines are routinely reviewed in these pages – are less exciting than this Bourgogne. While it musters greater sensual appeal in its youth than is typical for this bottling, I am quite confident it will stand the test of time as have its best exemplars from other vintages, and I would have no worries about planning on following it for 8-10 years.

Javillier’s 2007 Bourgogne Cuvee des Forgets is as appealing as any vintage of this blend that I can recall, and indeed an outstanding wine for its appellation. Lemon and orange blossom in the nose; Normandy cider tinged with citrus zest and brown spices on a vivacious yet subtly creamy and by no means meager palate; and a long, refreshing finish render this perfectly-proportioned Bourgogne an irresistible glass over the next 2-3 years and an excellent value.

The Javillier 2007 Meursault Clos du Cromin seems to represent a vintage’s reinforcement of the usually forward and flattering personality that typifies young wine from this site. Faded lily, very ripe peach, pineapple, and musk melon in the nose gain refreshment and vivacity on the palate from an infusion of fresh lemon and grapefruit, along with a lick of salt. This finishes lushly, generously ripe but without becoming fat or its decadence precluding some refreshment. The wines from this site can fool you, taking on some structure and showing a second phase of personality after a few years in bottle, but I would still be inclined to plan on drinking this one within the next 3-4 years.

Picked mid-September in its high-altitude, quarry-like environs above the village, Javillier’s 2007 Savigny-les-Beaune Montchenevoy is brightly citric from nose to tail, engendering vivacity and refreshment. Yet it is also subtly creamy in texture. Narcissus and orange blossom aromas; peach and nut oils mingled with fresh lemon on the palate; and a penetrating finish with a slightly shrill and metallic as well as chalky cast, suggest a wine to be paired judiciously at table now or given a 2-3 years in bottle to (in all likelihood) tone down a bit. Javillier admits that finding the sweet spot for fruit from this site is a challenge, and he appears to have missed it – if only by inches, or days – this year.

A Peter Vezan Selection (various importers), Paris; fax 011 33 1 42 55 42 93

There are only one and a half barriques of Javillier’s 2006 Meursault Charmes, a wine strikingly pits creamy, almost buttery texture, baked apple, vanilla, and nut oils against exuberant, juicy pink grapefruit. The result is harmonious and polished, with a finish both rich and refreshing. This should be worth following for at least 5-7 years during which it may well acquire more sense of mineral depth and interplay of flavor. 

The ever-experimental Patrick Javillier continues to pursue a unique approach, vinifying and elevating separate lots from each cru that in turn emphasize fruit, minerality, mouth feel, and structure; then assembling them late. (For a long time, Javillier distinguished as “Cuvee Speciale,” bottlings done later and without filtration. But in 2006, no such distinction was observed, and all of the wines are untiltered.) In 2003, Javillier adopted the contrarian viewpoint that the wines needed ample battonage and time on the lees to insure a structure that would compensate for low acidity, but in 2006 he felt the need to rack and bottle somewhat earlier than usual to preserve freshness and – in his words – “Burgundian character.” While he touts the virtues of this vintage for early drinking – and this is one address where 2004 and 2005 appear today to have the edge in quality, including potential longevity – samples of several of Javillier’s young 2006s that had taken on air for a day were, perhaps tellingly, more revelatory and satisfying that those freshly uncorked.

A Peter Vezan Selection (various importers), Paris; fax 011 33 1 42 55 42 93

The latest installment in a long-standing marriage of wine from Casse Tete and Les Murgers, Javillier’s 2006 Meursault Tete de Murgers smells of toasted grains, malt, honey, and lightly caramelized peach. Surprisingly bright and saline on the palate, it unites fresh citrus with its lower-toned, roasted elements in a finish of impressive persistence if not yet consummate harmony. Anywhere from 3-7 years of bottle aging would seem worthwhile, but even in the short term, this may well deploy its considerable forces more effectively. The dense, complex 2005 has a clear edge here, though.

Javillier’s 2006 Savigny-les-Beaune Montchenevoy displays, as it has in several recent vintages, the advantage of high ripeness to this quarry-like site high above Savigny, whose wines never seem to lack for acidity or strong mineral signature. Javillier has come to believe that his Savigny does not benefit from any new oak. This year, we have something with remarkably Chablis-like aromas and flavors of chicken stock, herbs, and lime; this wine’s juicy citricity, carnal richness, and shimmering minerality making for a fascinating, refreshing, and long-finishing display. Sleek and texturally refined, this shows a rare side of the 2006 vintage thanks to the uniqueness of its site and to Javillier’s vinificatory approach.

A Peter Vezan Selection (various importers), Paris; fax 011 33 1 42 55 42 93

Javillier’s 2006 Puligny-Montrachet Les Levrons consisting of a mere four barriques, one of them new features honeydew melon, brown spices, lime, and gooseberry preserves. A somewhat sweet-sour tendency all the way through to the finish seems to reflect the compromise that resulted from picking this early to preserve freshness, yet with botrytis already present. Hints of honey and meat reduction add interest in the finish, and the flavors of this silken-textured wine may knit itself more after a year or two in bottle.

The 2006 Meursault Clos du Cromin is deep green-gold in color and pungently spicy in aroma, suggesting a brush with botrytis in this clay-rich, relatively water-retentive site. Javillier believes in avoiding new barrels for this wine, not for the reason that prompts this reaction with his Savigny (namely retention of mineral character), but rather, he says, “because Clos du Cromin always has a tendency to be this said in English too much, very forward in its youth and only revealing its mineral side after some years in bottle.” In this instance we have elements of over-ripe pear, musk melon, litchi, and pink grapefruit; considerable amplitude and textural richness; and a zesty, pungently spicy finish that tends slightly toward drying and bitterness. Still, given the characteristic evolution of this wine, it should be worth revisiting after 2-3 years in bottle.

Generally a wine that plays above its classificatory league, Javillier’s single-vineyard 2006 Bourgogne Cuvee Oligocene is quite marked by its new wood as well as its brush with botrytis. Coconut and lanolin mingle with honey, pear nectar and lightly caramelized apricot. Fascinating carnal and mineral notes generally associated with this wine emerge on the back of the palate, and its combination of youthful firmness and substantial grip suggest that it will assert a compelling personality and should be worthy of at least 3-5 years cellaring.  I have recently had a couple of excellent 10-12 year old bottles of Cuvee Oligocene.

In 2003, Javillier adopted the contrarian viewpoint that the wines needed ample battonage and time on the lees to insure a structure that would compensate for low acidity, but in 2006 he felt the need to rack and bottle somewhat earlier than usual to preserve freshness and – in his words – “Burgundian character.” While he touts the virtues of this vintage for early drinking – and this is one address where 2004 and 2005 appear today to have the edge in quality, including potential longevity – samples of several of Javillier’s young 2006s that had taken on air for a day were, perhaps tellingly, more revelatory and satisfying that those freshly uncorked.

Effusively juicy peach, pineapple, lime, and tangerine make Javillier’s 2006 Bourgoge Cuvee des Forgets the most delicious rendition of this cuvee that I can recall in many years. Nor is it superficial: there is considerable mineral nuance on display here which, along with enhanced freshness and a diminution of alcohol, is contributed in part by a portion of Savigny-Les-Beaune from the stony, high Montchenevoy that Javillier blended in. Enjoy it through 2010.  

The ever-experimental Patrick Javillier continues to pursue a unique approach, vinifying and elevating separate lots from each cru that in turn emphasize fruit, minerality, mouth feel, and structure; then assembling them late. (For a long time, Javillier distinguished as “Cuvee Speciale,” bottlings done later and without filtration. But in 2006, no such distinction was observed, and all of the wines are untiltered.) In 2003, Javillier adopted the contrarian viewpoint that the wines needed ample battonage and time on the lees to insure a structure that would compensate for low acidity, but in 2006 he felt the need to rack and bottle somewhat earlier than usual to preserve freshness and – in his words – “Burgundian character.” While he touts the virtues of this vintage for early drinking – and this is one address where 2004 and 2005 appear today to have the edge in quality, including potential longevity – samples of several of Javillier’s young 2006s that had taken on air for a day were, perhaps tellingly, more revelatory and satisfying that those freshly uncorked.

A Peter Vezan Selection (various importers), Paris; fax 011 33 1 42 55 42 93

The hugely spicy 2003 Corton-Charlemagne Cuvee Speciale (white) is a hedonist’s delight. Thick, hugely concentrated, and velvety-textured, it coats the taster’s palate with super-ripe white fruits, roasted oak, a myriad of spices, and apple marmalade. Its outstanding depth (the deepest 2003 I tasted), power, balance, richness, and length are superb. Projected maturity: now-2020.   Bravo to Patrick Javillier!

A Peter Vezan Selection, Paris fax #011-33-1-42-55-42-93, importers include North Berkeley Imports, Berkeley, CA; tel. (800) 266-6585; also imported by David Shiverick, Langdon-Shiverick, Cleveland, OH; tel. (216) 861-6800; and Wines Ltd., Hanover, MD; tel. (800) 762-0662

description:

Its rich, creamy and yeasty aromas lead to a lush, smooth, and opulent personality. Big, broad, and expansive, the buttered popcorn-scented 2001 Corton-Charlemagne Cuvee Speciale is a deep, sexy, medium-bodied wine. Its concentrated, rich, lush layers of buttered nuts, spices, and minerals linger on the palate for 30 seconds or more. Projected maturity: now-2010.

To Patrick Javillier, 2001 was a classic vintage with normal ripeness levels and problem-free fermentations, “I really don’t see where the problems are ... total acidity was in the 5.5 to 6.0 range and finished pHs were between 3.2 and 3.25, it’s all very classic.”

Demure pear aromas can be found in the nose of the 2001 Meursault Les Clous Cuvee Speciale. This wonderful wine is seamless, elegant, loaded with flavor, and possesses a long, drawn-out, expressive finish. Broad layers of buttery pears can be found throughout this suave wine’s character. Anticipated maturity: now-2008. 

To Patrick Javillier, 2001 was a classic vintage with normal ripeness levels and problem-free fermentations, “I really don’t see where the problems are ... total acidity was in the 5.5 to 6.0 range and finished pHs were between 3.2 and 3.25, it’s all very classic.”

product_name: Meursault "Cuvée Tête de Murger Mise Spéciale"
description:
An elegant, light to medium-bodied wine with considerable depth of fruit, the 2001 Meursault Tete de Murger Cuvee Speciale reveals aromas of white flowers, stones, apples, and pears. Supple, hugely spicy, and highly detailed, its powerful mineral flavors linger in the exceedingly long finish. Anticipated maturity: now-2009. 

To Patrick Javillier, 2001 was a classic vintage with normal ripeness levels and problem-free fermentations, “I really don’t see where the problems are ... total acidity was in the 5.5 to 6.0 range and finished pHs were between 3.2 and 3.25, it’s all very classic.”

Exotic aromas of apricots, pears, and peaches can be found in the nose of Javillier’s 2001 Meursault Charmes Cuvee Speciale. This medium-bodied, plush wine is jam-packed with fruit. Its supple waves of pulp-laden pears and jammy apricots are intermingled with compelling hints of an underlying minerality. Projected maturity: now-2010. 

To Patrick Javillier, 2001 was a classic vintage with normal ripeness levels and problem-free fermentations, “I really don’t see where the problems are ... total acidity was in the 5.5 to 6.0 range and finished pHs were between 3.2 and 3.25, it’s all very classic.”

Spiced pears are found in the wonderful nose of the 2001 Puligny-Montrachet Le Levron Cuvee Speciale. An expansive yet crystalline wine, its light to medium-bodied personality offers flavors reminiscent of fresh flowers and gravel. Fresh, pure, and delicately-etched, it will be at its best if consumed over the next 4-5 years. 

To Patrick Javillier, 2001 was a classic vintage with normal ripeness levels and problem-free fermentations, “I really don’t see where the problems are ... total acidity was in the 5.5 to 6.0 range and finished pHs were between 3.2 and 3.25, it’s all very classic.”

Possibly the finest Savigny-Les-Beaune Javillier has produced, the 2001 Les Montchenevoy Cuvee Speciale displays delightful floral, mineral, and talcum powder aromas. Juicy, plump, flavorful, and satin-textured, it offers lush layers of ripe, pulp-laden pears loaded with spices. Drink this expressive beauty over the next 3-4 years.  

To Patrick Javillier, 2001 was a classic vintage with normal ripeness levels and problem-free fermentations, “I really don’t see where the problems are ... total acidity was in the 5.5 to 6.0 range and finished pHs were between 3.2 and 3.25, it’s all very classic.”

Light to medium-bodied, the 2001 Meursault Clos du Cromin displays fresh white fruit aromas and scents. Plump, rich, and delineated, it is loaded with spicy pear flavors that linger in its impressive finish. Drink it over the next 5 years. 

To Patrick Javillier, 2001 was a classic vintage with normal ripeness levels and problem-free fermentations, “I really don’t see where the problems are ... total acidity was in the 5.5 to 6.0 range and finished pHs were between 3.2 and 3.25, it’s all very classic.”

Aromatically demure, the 2001 Meursault Narvaux is a well-focused, satin-textured wine. Lush, juicy, and plump, it offers pretty spice and pear flavors in its feminine, refined personality. It should also be drunk over the next 5 years.

To Patrick Javillier, 2001 was a classic vintage with normal ripeness levels and problem-free fermentations, “I really don’t see where the problems are ... total acidity was in the 5.5 to 6.0 range and finished pHs were between 3.2 and 3.25, it’s all very classic.”

Spicy pear aromas can be found in the nose of the 2001 Bourgogne Cuvee des Forgets Cuvee Speciale. Lush, fresh, and bright, it is light to medium-bodied. This wine offers a lovely array of lemon, mineral, and apple flavors in its expressive personality. It should be consumed over the next 3 years. 

To Patrick Javillier, 2001 was a classic vintage with normal ripeness levels and problem-free fermentations, “I really don’t see where the problems are ... total acidity was in the 5.5 to 6.0 range and finished pHs were between 3.2 and 3.25, it’s all very classic.”

Having spent more time on its lees than the regular bottling, the 2001 Meursault Les Tillets Cuvee Speciale has developed a fuller, more complete personality. Its exceedingly spicy nose leads to a fresh, lush character composed of flower-laced pears. Light to medium-bodied, it lacks the length of Javillier’s best 2001s. Projected maturity: now-2006. 

To Patrick Javillier, 2001 was a classic vintage with normal ripeness levels and problem-free fermentations, “I really don’t see where the problems are ... total acidity was in the 5.5 to 6.0 range and finished pHs were between 3.2 and 3.25, it’s all very classic.”

The tightly wound 2001 Bourgogne Cuvee Oligocene has appealing floral aromas. Light to medium-bodied and satin-textured, it reveals a lemon-infused core of fruit. Drink it over the next 2-3 years. 

To Patrick Javillier, 2001 was a classic vintage with normal ripeness levels and problem-free fermentations, “I really don’t see where the problems are ... total acidity was in the 5.5 to 6.0 range and finished pHs were between 3.2 and 3.25, it’s all very classic.”

The 2001 Meursault Les Tillets displays spicy white fruit and flower aromas. On the palate, this light to medium-bodied wine reveals pure, detailed floral and perfumed flavors in its delicate character. Drink it over the next 3 years. 

To Patrick Javillier, 2001 was a classic vintage with normal ripeness levels and problem-free fermentations, “I really don’t see where the problems are ... total acidity was in the 5.5 to 6.0 range and finished pHs were between 3.2 and 3.25, it’s all very classic.”

Loads of spiced white fruits can be found in the aromatics of the 2000 Meursault Charmes Mise Speciale. This refined wine is medium-bodied, pure, and satin-textured. It exhibits a lovely panoply of apples, pears, apricots, and a faint hint of lychee nuts whose effects linger in its long, supple finish. Drink it over the next 8-9 years.
